												Sid Meier's Railroads! is the first train tycoon game I've ever played. I don't know why; tycoon games are one of my favorite subgenres of simulation games, and I love any games having to do with transportation of any type, from cars to ships to farming equipment. In saying that, know that this review is from someone who loves the genre and trains despite being relatively new to the railroad management subset.Sid Meier's Railroads! is a game that kept pleasantly surprising me. I went into this game figuring I would be building trains and connecting the tracks to various destinations. I hadn't known it would be this in depth, and yet so easy to learn. The game and its userface is extremely user friendly, and it has a short tutorial to teach you the basics. Everything else is figured out by playing scenarios. Since I was brand new to this type of game, I began by selecting a multiplayer map but electing to play first on my own so I could figure things out. That's when I realized that even when not playing competitively, this game is a ton of fun.You start out by having a city with a small track already built that you can build off of (also, all maps can be randomized, so playing through on the same maps over and over again is different every time). You need to then decide where to go from there. Different cities request different products, and you can deliver it to them from either suppliers or other cities. This gets to be a little more in depth because you can end up having a multiple step process to have one train deliver products to various cities (for example, Train A can be set up to pick up corn from a farm supplier, deliver it to City A, City A will then convert corn to food, Train A will take food to City B, etc.). You can also have trains deliver passengers and mail from city to city. Over the course of history, trains are unlocked that have better performance. It's extraordinarily simple to upgrade these trains to better trains that have been unlocked, and all without hindering its route. This is essentially the type of gameplay you can expect. To make things more interesting, however, depending on what cities and products you decide to utilize, cities and suppliers will grow to supply your demand and vice versa. By growing, suppliers can supply more resources and more quickly, while cities may be able to hold stock of more resources while space opens up where you can build your own industries. Cities will also request supplies from time to time, offering a cash reward for a certain product. These are some of the reasons that playing a fairly long game refrains from being boring; options are constantly opening up for you. Competitive mode with the AI is also fun, though I prefer the single player building aspect better myself. With the AI, they will do all the things you do, building tracks, causing cities and suppliers to grow, etc. The difference here is that you are obviously competing for the goal you have set, while also having the option to buy stock in your competitors and eventually merge or liquidate their company by completely buying them out--provided you have enough money.While this game has been a blast (it makes me regret not trying a railroad management game before this), it does have its problems. On modern systems (I have Windows 7 64bit, for example) the game begins to crash once a good amount of railroads and trains have been built. The game is set by default to restrict itself to using only 1 GB of RAM, and once you've been in a game for a half hour or so, it will surpass this and begin crashing to the desktop. HOWEVER, there are fixes for this (see the community forums). I downloaded a .exe file from http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Sid_Meier%27s_Railroads! that fixed everything, and haven't had a crash since. Also, the game is set by default to autosave, which saves your game every 60 seconds. Needless to say, even when it was crashing, I'd simply start it right back up and be just seconds away from where I was.In summary, this game is an amazing game that I would recommend to anyone, particularly simulation, tycoon, and management fans. I haven't been so instantly engrossed in a game in quite some time. I'm so happy I found this!

This way, players are given a chance to enjoy the game and its numerous traits, regardless of their previous experiences with train sims. Also, there's a choice of over 30 different industries to purchase and organize, 20 resources to manage and over 30 unique train models to produce and utilize. Each scenario revolves around completing a wide range of tasks, after which you can look forward to many cool bonuses - thus improving your cash balance and instituting a more stable economy for future endeavors.Looking at the graphics, Sid Meier's Railroads includes just about everything you can hope to find in a train-sim. Realistic and colorful surroundings and detailed locomotive models manage to capture the player's eye almost straight away. As your very own mass transit system begins to take shape, you'll be able to acknowledge the developer's admirable attention to detail. In closing, this game is catchy and has a little something for everyone.

(My favorite from the series is 2)

												I've always loved business simulations and the kid version of me loves trains. Even though I have both of those things in me, I just didn't like the thought of a railroad tycoon type of game even if it is from the great Sid Meier.After playing it though, its an enjoyable little game with a competitive element (if you chose). You chose the era to start and era to end the game. The game basically consists of you connecting resources, supply and demand. Resources get generated, such as oil, grapes, crops, livestock, minerals and so on. Then you connect them to towns that need them. A town will have one of three things demanding these resources. You setup the tracks, then make a train route to bring them in. It is just that simple. The towns will grow into cities. When they take the resources, based on what buildings they have, such as livestock and crops will turn into food. Minerals will turn into gold and so on. Then you export them to other towns that need them. The towns will grow into cities and get more buildings and need more resources for you to bring them. New towns will generate too.The real twist here is a competitive element (if you have AI opponents). Even in single player, you can have up to 3 AI opponents (or no competition). A game of Monopoly really. You can buy stock in the other companies. You can sell your own stock for money. You don't just get money doing routes. You also get money buying facilities in towns and cities. However, when you try to buy them, you'll end up bidding against the AI competition if you have any. You can also construct facilities yourself for a flat fee if there are any available lots in a town or city. This means, you can play Monopoly and never actually build a railroad. There's a buzz buying out your competition, but I never really felt all that threatened by them, even with all of their tracks around me. The twist of having stock and buying buildings makes the game a lot of fun in a game that wouldn't warrant replays. It is always the same map, BUT there is an option to randomize the land and cities which is very nice.With all of that said, its a fun, relaxing, yet competitive game (if you have AI or do multi-player), but the only downside is, there's not much variety here. Once you've played one full game, you've played it all. There are victory conditions, but they're not front and center, so there's no focus on it. At $10, if you're into Monopoly style games, or railroading in general, give it a go. Otherwise, wait for a sale.

There are a lot of train games for the PC, but few are as lightweight and approachable as this one.I’ve heard it said that everyone has a little fondness for trains and this game is sure to appeal to that little bit in a big way.Contrary to Sid’s flagship Civilization series, ease of use seems to be the secret ingredient behind Railroads and its engrossing gameplay. Setting up your first station is pips and in no time at all you’ll have an entire network of trains delivering everything from passengers, coal, food and automobiles to the various towns and industries looking to reward you for your efforts.The scalable difficulty in Railroads is a real winner too as it allows you to tailor how in-depth an experience you’re after. The easiest difficulty will allow trains to pass through each other without delay whereas a harder mode will demand you route trains carefully, punishing you with delays should you mangle your track layout.Once the money starts rolling in though, things get surprisingly addictive as you sit back and watch your trains dutifully trundling back and forth between stations and annexes, generating you cash with a very satisfying ka-ching! sound effect in accompaniment.For less ruthlessly minded players at least, the multiplayer component in Railroads is somewhat muted, with not a whole lot of interaction on offer but the whole aspect of buying out other players on the stock market gives it some real teeth. I remember once hearing it described as a corporate deathmatch more than a train simulation; something that might not be too far away from the truth!Railroads was well received on release and enjoys a small fan base to this day, but it’s a shame that the move to 64-bit computer systems has hampered this title’s ability to run effectively on newer computers. Just be sure that you check the online guides on how to get this title working properly!Even so, it’s still a great way to waste a couple of hours on a Sunday afternoon that’s for sure.Read the full retrospective at my blog »[www.celjaded.com]

												If you're a fan of OpenTTD, Railroad Tycoon 2, RRT3 or similar games: I do not recommend this game. It's style over substance.Having just played Railroads (I stopped when it crashed) I can't believe this has so many positive reviews on Steam and magazines via Metacritic. It came out in 2007, but OpenTTD was more than alive at that time and far superior. This game is brain-dead. It's a train network game, except you can't properly adjust the train network! The auto-track placement and the complete lack of manual signals ruins this game. You get signals where you don't want signals and you can't remove them. The signals do nothing more than claim the section of track from here to the next signal, but that doesn't work when the game is placing a million pointless signals. It doesn't matter if you always make sure to use the green 'extend' rather than the yellow 'fork' placement. The game still produces insane signal placement. I had one stretch of nice smooth track with a signal at either end. I use the "double up" button and double up the entire length and now suddenly I have 6 signals right next to each other in the middle of the track, which was pointless and just messed everything up if I wanted to try and share that line. Creating passing places is also extremely difficult and trains will often just blunder their way down the track until two are in a head-to-head deadlock either side of the signals. There's no way to reverse the train so the only solution is to nuke the train and buy it again.Also: the fully stocked train is usually the same length as the track between the resource producer and consumer! There's no room for maneuver, which further exacerbates the no-passing-places and signalling problem.Because of the stupid signals and the uber long trains, you basically have to dedicated a line to each train. Trains cannot share track. I find that pretty demented and it basically reduces the game down to laying a track, build some stations, placing a track to exclusively dominate a section of track and then simply sitting back and watching. There's no real decision making. You can't sit their endlessly tweaking a track for extra efficiency as you can in OpenTTD.Also: The track-layer is also really finicky. When trying to create branches I often ended up with lots of tiny bits of track that took me ages to delete because it perfectly overlaps the other bit of track. Given that "lay track" is one of the 3 primary things you can do, it gets annoying fast.

												So, the first thing you need to know about this game is that this is in fact the original Railroad Tycoon, it's just been renamed and updated to play on modern OS such as Vista and Windows 7 (see other reviews about compatibility with newer).  There's a version of RT1 on Steam that DOES NOT play on modern OS.  But don't buy it if you're not working on an antique; you don't need it.As for the "RAM-filled" crashing glitch, definitely dowload the patch mentioned in other reviews, but before that turn off autosave.  It saves every minute for some god-awful reason, which pushes you towards the ram limit quickly.  With that turned off, I've played for six + hours without a hitch (though I also downloaded the player-made patch, so I can't tell which did the trick, if not both).As to gameplay, as another reviewer said, there are about 15 maps, each with scenarios that take about an hour.  However,  you can play them on three different difficulty levels, with 0 to 3 AI players, and each has gold, silver, and bronze victory conditions, so there are quite a few permutations available to keep you interested.  You can also randomize the town locations, but even without that, each time you play a map, the msc resources (lumber mills, cattle pastures, grain farms, etc) randomly generate their locations.The most fun part about this game for me is efficiency of transport.  You can have up to four tracks per station, upgrade engines, stations, and towns to make them faster and with higher return values, and also buy properties in the towns for extra income.  This diversification of investments is more important when you're playing against AI---basically, you can own a piece of your competetor's pie! (Or they'll fight you for yours....)The game is one of Sid Meyer's best from back in the day, and it balances well the ability to play as a sandbox builder vs a super-competitve crazy land.  (Part of the point of the game from the competitve pov is clearly to make 900 foot high roman-arched bridges over your competetors' tracks.)  If you play it like that, it's downright zany.  Truly, early Sid Meyer.  But it's also got great mechanics and logic, as per par for SM games.The graphics are also super cute, which I particularly like.  They stand the test of time.A couple of tips to players: There's a feature that lets you go-to cities (bottom left of control panel), which is really helpful for maps that center around places you've never lived/been. (Like various parts of Europe, in my case.)  Too, you can press + or - to increase or decrease the elevation of your tracks.  There's no other way to get a tunnel when it wants to auto-build you a bridge.  Also, holding the mouse wheel allows you to swivel the map, which you can't do in RT2.If you're wondering wether to get RT1 or 2, I like both, but for different reasons.  I think RT1 is a better game, though I remember playing RT2 way more as a kid.  RT1 is more about building and logistics, whereas I'd say RT2 is more about making money.  It's also a way harder game.  The graphics in RT2 use the Tropico engine, which is actually rather frustrating for that game.  The camera also doesn't swivel; you get four fixed viewpoints.  I could never find a satisfying map angel in RT2, and I don't know about you, but that just drives me absoutely nuts.All in all, a very solid game, a favorite oldie, and definitely worth the tiny price.  It's one of my top favorites of all time, right up there with Roller Coaster Tycoon.  Go ahead and buy it!LONG STORY SHORT:Pros:+ Very logical gameplay+ Well-ordered+ Cute graphics+ Short scenario play so you can have fun but still go outside and live your life+ Multiple scenario difficulty options + Some randomization of every map+ Town Randomization available on any map+ 0 - 3 AI players+ Kids can play but adults will be challenged too+ Historic events and engine progression is sort of in the background but a lot of fun for people who are buffs/nerds of that variety :)Cons+ Need some initial fussing with it to keep it from crashing+ Game starts to freeze on my computer when I get close to having the entire map networked (I'm on a laptop though)+ If you're connecting existing tracks, make sure the arrow cursors are green, not yellow. You will get better at it, but initially you will lay track to nowhere that you can't delete because your trains are running over it and you will curse SO MUCH.+ Can't upgrade all train engines at once + Only about 15 maps; can't recall if there's a fully randomized map option.+ There's human multiplayer on this game but I'm not sure how to make it work these days; haven't tried to use it

												Sid Meier's Railroad Tycoon was the third game I ever purchased back in the 1800's, no, I'm kidding (Though it feels like it at times.) I actually purchased it in 1990 not long after acquiring my first desktop PC. I have played the series religiously since. I have roughly 100 hours in this game in the original 2006 disc retail box version. It certainly isn't a successor to the venerable Railroad Tycoon III, but it's still quite enjoyable if you realize this going in. The game is more of a "beer & pretzels" type real time strategy game with an emphasis  on attracting more casual type gamers. The game has a charming art style more akin to an HO or N scale model train layout than the ostensible real world look of the previous Railroad Tycoon games. Industry acquisitions and playing the stock market against other AI railroad barons seem to have become more important in this title with train consists and railroad track signaling unfortunately taking a back seat. Being able to build your own train consists is possible (and necessary), but the importance seems to have been watered down compared to previous titles. Manual signaling has been removed altogether. The scenarios and their variety are adequate, but pale dim in comparison to Railroad Tycoon III. Firaxis encouraged fans to build maps and scenarios to add to the scenarios available. These additional scenarios can still be found on fansites. The game originally included multiplayer. Be advised, this feature has been truncated from the game entirely. The Steam version of Sid Meier's Railroads! has no multiplayer feature whatsover. My boxed version would not run on Windows Vista without crashing to the desktop continually. It runs on my current iteration of Windows 7 64-bit, but there is a known bug concerning multi-core processors the game doesn't like. I noticed specifically when building long stretches of track I would get crashes to the desktop. I've played the Steam version for over two dozen hours as of this writing, and I rarely get a desktop crash anymore. I miss the previous versions of Sid Meier's wonderful railroad games, but oddly, this one has become my favorite of the series. Despite its lack of seriousness, it's still challenging. The game exudes Sid Meier's influence in every pixel. It's colorful art style blooms beautifully, and the sound design which has been lovingly crafted really adds to the ambience. Music from each time period sets the tone and changes along with the times. Zooming in to view the busy animations of each industry and city building is the icing on the cake.

												i give this game a positive review (with reservations) because i love railroads and the general design of this game is a lot of fun. However, it does lack polish and seems somewhat unfinished. For just a few bucks, though, i think the fun value is definitely worth some of the annoyances. i definitely wish they had loved this one a little more.The Good: Graphics Music/sound AI is reasonable Easy and fun to get into and play Varied strategic options Animations; Lock Cam mode Gives the feel of a real model railroadThe Bad: Train routing logic/algorithmTruly horrible stuff here. Seems like the programmers outdid themselves making this difficult on players. You cannot specify one-way tracks in the game. Also, the track signals are nearly meaningless as trains regularly sit forever for no reason (it seems) at green signals while often ignoring red ones. This often creates traffic jams which cannot be easily resolved without deleting trains. Actually, what is usually happening is that trains won't move past a green signal until they see a clear route to a station and a 'free' platform track (part of the routing logic). The game will usually suggest creating another parallel track somewhere to resolve the problem. Better solutions seem to be: Create only point to point tracks limited to one train whenever possible and avoid point to loop, loop to loop, and "shared mainline" routes (although the latter can be done if done properly) Always have at least two station platform tracks at shared stations  Avoid adding 'extra' signals between stations Game interface/ease of play conveniencesSorry, but they didn't spend much time working out how to make the interface user-friendly for ease-of-play. Even the original Railroad Tycoon is much better here. There's only about a hundred or so improvements which could be made to make the game play easier (like adding opponents stations and cargo to the routing/consist interface, putting the opponents stations 'colored dots' on the mini-map, having various messages come up about events (such as opponents building into new towns, etc.)), etc., etc., etc.As a result, unless you want to get far behind your opponents (who build track INSTANTLY) you have to pause the game a lot to look around and see what's going on, gather information, etc., which wouldn't have to be done if the interface provided better information. Game scale and paceThe game is most fun if played in REAL-TIME (without stop-and-go pausing) but, though it starts slowly, as the players progress and there are more trains and stations to manage the pace of the game increases DRAMATICALLY which makes it harder and harder for the player to study and manage all the changing variables. This occurs because as the players' incomes and earning power go up, the costs to build go down.Best thing to do is keep your routes as simple as possible, don't put many trains on shared sections of track, and prefer creating new routes rather than fixing old ones (which is costly in terms of 'game-time'). Financial and stock market models simplistic and silly Track building (especially bridges and tunnels) probably not costly enough No track or station maintenance, only on engines All industries cost the same (and probably too little) No local market rates (i.e. as in RRT3), only global ones Costs go down rather than up No borrowing or interest rates Can't protect yourself from being bought out no matter how many stock shares ownedAs a result of this last, every game ends pretty much the same way - a race to stockpile cash to buy out your opponents.  Only 15 scenarios, 8 of them multiplayer (is there multiplayer somewhere?)The Ugly:Game crashes a lot due to memory errors and flaws in the construction mode when the mouse cursor is held over animations. Supposedly there is a fix for the memory problem.There's more, but i'll stop here.CONCLUSIONOkay, so if there's so much that needed to be fixed and improved, why do i recommend this game? Well, despite all this, when it isn't crashing it's SO MUCH DARN FUN!:)So, for a few bucks i say OK, but sadly, i wonder how good this one could have been if they cared to put out their best product.:(

												Despite its age, there aren't many games that can be classified in the same category as Railroads. To describe the mechanics of the game, you start with a number of cities, each with a supply, demand, and number of industries. As a railroad engineer, you connect cities by connecting them with railroads, buying trains, and designing trade routes. By using industries to convert resources to products, and then selling those products to larger cities, victory can be achieved in a number of virtual decades. Mutliplayer, unfortunately, is dead, which is sad because it would be an intriguing concept to have several players working together (or against eachother) to build up the largest stockpile of funds as cities are connected in a web of railroads.This game is addicting, there's plenty of scenarios to play through, and plenty of maps to use. Furthermore, by randomizing cities descriptions and locations, there's a near-endless amount of ways this game can be played.For the current price, there's no reason why a fan of Sid Meier shouldn't have this in their collection. Get it!

												My husband and I both LOVE this game. There's a lot of depth to the game that really makes it challenging! When you first start up, it's best to follow the tutorial just so you know the controls. Then, see how much money you can make by shipping the correct goods to the right city--but watch for in case a town develops into a city and wants new items! You can also build/purchase a company in different cities so that you can earn even more profits. Playing with AI or other players adds a whole new level to the game when you can't use or build onto others' railroads. Instead, you have to lay your tracks around or over their tracks to get to where you need to go. Playing with another human is fun as well; hubby and I quickly found that you can force players to pay an outrageous amount of money for something they really want--or something they don't want you to get. At the same time, if you buy a company on their rail tracks, they can simply stop shipping items to your company--and you lose all the potential profits you could be making. If you make enough money, you can purchase the stocks of other players, and potentially buy out their company. Be careful about if you choose to liquidate them or merge them.... Liquidation adds all of monetary value of their stuff the the monetary value of your stocks---not to your bank account. However, if you do choose to merge their company with yours (allowing you to combine your tracks, edit theirs, and so on), you'll find that the AI tends to be rather stupid and make money--somehow--from shipping a train full of magic nothing back and forth between two cities which requires a lot of poking around to make all their stuff actually profitable for you. lol.If you like management strategy games--this is definitely worth giving a try!The only downside is the game will crash a LOT when  you first get it. I circumnavigated this issue by simply saving the game every two minutes and then loading the game from the saved files everytime it crashed anyways. There IS a fix for this crash issue somewhere in the forums. Hubby has WIndows7 and I have Windows8, and the fix (which called for replacing the game file with another one offered in the forums--or, alternatively, simply typing in a few coding changes in the game file manually) resolved the crashing issue for both of our computers. Once fixed, however, the game will provide hours of challenging track-laying and course-plotting to hopefully make you millions (in in-game currency of course, lol)!

However, if you do choose to merge their company with yours (allowing you to combine your tracks, edit theirs, and so on), you'll find that the AI tends to be rather stupid and make money--somehow--from shipping a train full of magic nothing back and forth between two cities which requires a lot of poking around to make all their stuff actually profitable for you. lol.If you like management strategy games--this is definitely worth giving a try!The only downside is the game will crash a LOT when  you first get it. I circumnavigated this issue by simply saving the game every two minutes and then loading the game from the saved files everytime it crashed anyways. There IS a fix for this crash issue somewhere in the forums. Hubby has WIndows7 and I have Windows8, and the fix (which called for replacing the game file with another one offered in the forums--or, alternatively, simply typing in a few coding changes in the game file manually) resolved the crashing issue for both of our computers. Once fixed, however, the game will provide hours of challenging track-laying and course-plotting to hopefully make you millions (in in-game currency of course, lol)!

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												Ugh.  I'm a big Sid Meier fan, and played a great deal of Railroad Tycoon 1 and 2, but this thing is a grave disappointment.  The gameplay is excessively easy; run some track and trains, money pours in, woop.  There's little need to fine-tune your trains or manifests, or even plan ahead.  The graphics are dated by modern standards of course but not bad, but cartoonish; all bright colors and everything lit as if by a spotlight.  Mountains are vastly exaggerated, making it hard to see routes.  Economics is limited; there seems to be no limit to how much of a good you can send to one city, so there's little need to search out new markets.  You can't issue stock, merge with other companies, or even take out a freakin' loan!  There's no march of technology: auto factories in the 1830s?!  The UI is OK, but a little click-happy; basic keyboard shortcuts like Esc to close a window aren't always implemented.Quibbling aside, there are two deal-breakers: first, the maps are small, a fraction of the size of RR1 or RR2.  They're also cramped, packed with towns and industries.  There's no lonely prairie where trains rumble on for miles between stops.  Games are short.  It really lacks any epic feel.  This is killer because there are only a handful of maps to play, and a handful of goals to achieve on each.  Having played four short games, I've seen about everything there is to see.Second, the tracks.  Laying single track is fine; the program automatically adds tunnels, bridges, and overpasses reasonably well.  HOWEVER, hit the double track button and you get your own personal demon from hell to torment you.  The simplest operations now require careful planning and possibly some build-it-and-delete-it cycles.  Trains will take the wrong track and fail to recognize tracks that exist.  Nothing's more maddening than carefully laying out track, buying a train, setting up the route... and seeing that the train won't return to the first station, because it thinks it can only go one way on a certain arbitrary segment of track... somewhere.  Except maybe having that happen over, and over, and over again.Oh, and it's already crashed.So what's good?  Station management is simpler; you no longer have to worry about exactly catching all of a city's industries, build a station and it just works.  Trains won't get stalled to 1 MPH on steep slopes.  For an RR1 or RR2 fan, it's all very familiar, the learning curve is tiny (don't bother with the tutorial, just start a game).  Some maps have custom industries, like wineries and fromageries in France, a cute touch.  The "patents" system is kinda cool - you bid against the other players in a brief open auction for a ten-year bonus of some sort.  When laying track in a city, the buildings will rearrange themselves to make room, at no cost, which is hugely refreshing compared to the massive PITA that could be in RRT2, where you sometimes had to demolish chunks of a city at great expense so your railroad could catch the city and cross the river.This thing was half-baked when it was released, and never brought up to speed.  I'm tempted to try RR3; as long as it's halfway stable, it's sure to be better than this.

												I loved Railroad Tycoon 3 and Railroad Tycoon 2, and I'd read enough negative reviews of this game comparing it to the RTC series that I held off on purchasing this game.  Well, since it doesn't look like we're ever going to get a true Railroad Tycoon 4 and this game was on sale for $5.99 I decided, sure, it's not any more expensive than a Big Mac Value Meal, I'll give it a shot.  Well, I can say this game wasn't even worth the $5.99.I knew the economic simulation of the RTC series wouldn't be present in this game - no fluctuating prices, no inefficient "Tycoonatrons" moving materials and goods independent of railroad to simuate how the real world works, no independent industrial growth.  That was fine.  But there are only 6 or so types of raw materials, and demand never ceases so all you have to do is hook up more and more supply facilities to the cities.  Oh and there's very few cities either, and no growth caps - Los Angeles and Tehachapi will both grow into "Metropolises" once you give them their materials.  The maps are TINY and build out very fast.At first I was pleasantly surprised by some innovations Sid Meier has introduced to the track-building mechanics:  Tracks and stations can go anywhere in cities, no more tedious weaving around or knocking down buildings to get your station into a city, or having to locate in a certain spot to cover as much of a sprawling city as possible.  Just plop your track and station down and the buildings automatically move around to get out of your way!  Wonderful!  Unfortunately, the double track mechanic is awful and making parallel tracks connect to each other takes an act of God.  I found myself constantly having to build switches between the parallel tracks, and even high priority trains stop every time they encounter a switch.  Even worse, there is no undo button AND NO BULLDOZER BUTTON so once you build a track, you're stuck with it.  My tracks looked like disorganized monstrosities because of this, with trains constantly bogging down at a dozen unnecessary switch signals.  At least there aren't any sanding/water towers required here...but it really doesn't matter.Once you get into a position to buy out your competitors, make sure to liquidate their assets rather than absorb them, because absorbing a well-established competitor will instantly bring the game (and I don't run a cheap system) to its' knees with freezes and eventual crashes, and that's what brought me back to this screen, completely fed up.I don't know how this game got through the play-testing phase of development.  The simplistic economy is a disappointment after the fantastic Railroad Tycoon 3 but I can handle it.... but the track building snafus are just awful, and overall I find this game just wasn't enjoyable even when it does operate smoothly.  I hope we get a true successor to Railroad Tycoon 3 someday.

												This is a gorgeous, personality-filled, light-load, fun packed game.I first played this title a decade or so ago, and I knew from the moment I first opened a map and started building my own little railway network that this would be a title typical of the Sid Meier games (Pirates!, etc) - a polished, balanced, aesthetically pleasing game which takes the concept of relaxing gameplay into active consideration.You take on the role of a railroad tycoon, unleashed into various theaters and tasked with fulfilling certain rail objectives. You start with one town and a single station from which to grow your empire. You connect to another nearby town and start shuffling wheat back and forth. Soon you spot a third town and head off to it, gambling on a long stretch of track that you have to borrow to afford... Connecting to the new location and the huge herds of beef cows it boasts, you realise with a jolt that you have nowhere to sell the cows. Frantically you search around the map for a town which buys them, realising that the nearest market lies three or four cities away. The size of your task has grown, the ambition of your railway firm has grown, the scope of the gameplay has grown, the payoff in economic fun has Doubled, Tripled, Fourbled and Fibled! You can't reach the far cattle buyers just yet, but you are able to shuttle passengers between your little network of towns, so you build a secondary line to your freight route and get shuttlin'. You spot marginal gains in the buyers and sellers of nearby hamlets and pounce, connecting them to your network, watching them grow and provide more returns! You upgrade trains - such speed! Such pulling power! - and soon hills are as easy to scale as descents, and suddenly you finally deliver those 12 cars of cattle to the distant metropolis that is dying for them and your bank balance goes ka-ching!Dem monies, tho.This game is just solid gold fun. An elaboration on typical economic management sims, the ability to custom build your own rail routes and work out new and efficient track layouts and schedules makes you really feel like the original Isambad Kingdom Brunel. The formula wears thin once you have conquored all you can, once you have maxed out every advance and the finite maps are chock full of railway lines, but the race to this endgame is just so fun that you keep on coming back again and again. Then restarting. The wide range of maps is also quite nice, since each map is of varied difficulty and houses a goodly chunk of play hours and replayability.It's dirty cheap so buy it, and enjoy it, I love it to bits.9/10.

												This game outshines more recent clones like Train Fever by a long chalk!  Gameplay is easier, more logical and intuitive, and the graphics are much, much better.  The constant crashing mentioned by other reviewers -- runtime errors, the software algorithms run into logical defeats -- can be reduced greatly if you daisychain your tracks as per the turorial and don't try being "too clever" with collection/dropoffs on extended lines, or completing (quite by accident) a "circuit", since the calculation tables used are flat arrays, not paradox-susceptible loops.  Playing with an AI oponent also increases chance of crashing, as the AI is essentially stupid. This means half the supplied scenarios, which depend on you buying out all the stocks in AI opponent companies, cannot be played beyond sandbox mode. Using older graphics cards can make the animation jumpy, so you'll need a PCI-express based system at the very least.  My best AGP card, an ATI Radeon 1650 Pro, had trouble keeping up.  This is a wonderful "update" on an old PC title from the DOS era, and worth looking into, whether or not your played the original.One small niggle: no "passing time" control beyond normal and ffwd, the set scenarios are time-dependent (in game years) and this ticks away faster than you can build up your empire to the required "win" standard.  A "llama" or "tortoise" speed would be helpful.  Otherwise you have to put the game on pause to assess your next moves, and on pause you make no profit.Another niggle: not enough single-player scenarios.  Once you've learned how to play without crashing every five minutes (it's possible, I've done it), you work your way through the provided quest maps very quickly. 												Kind of have a love/hate relationship with this game.  For myself, it is an addicting little title.  It is fun to play for a few hours and come back to a few days later.  The game doesn't have much depth, however, and mastering it takes very little time.  It is a fun little Stratedgy/Sim but has a ton of flaws as well.  Being an older game, some of those can be forgiven.So, the Pro's.As mentioned, I find this title to be a bit addictive.  The map randomization allows for a different game each time you play.  The graphics aren't bad, considering this came out in 2006, and it's one of the newest Train management games out there.    The game runs very smoothly and is fun to watch.  You're always looking for new resources and at your existing track, looking for the best routes and tie-in's.Now, the Con's.Crashes on Windows 7 unless you get the Patched .exe from the forums.  Online multiplayer service is no longer supported.  Cheaty and annoying AI, which isn't very smart and tends to build track which would normally be impossible for you to do so yourself.  Very limited city management.  Games run on a timeline which makes everything feel very linear.  No real Sandbox mode.  Winner is usually determined by who starts out in the "sweet spot" with best resources near them.  Map edges are not very well utilized and you tend to have everyone too close when starting.Sometimes, the AI in the game becomes really annoying.  They'll neglect resources which they could use and instead lay track to a city you are already running a line to, hindering both you and themselves.  Also, like most AI, they do as they please and it makes me wonder if they actually have the $$$ to do what they did.In the end, it's a very simple game mainly about train management, routing, and gaining $$$ the fastest in order to win.  It would be nice if it had much more management, maybe maintenance costs or random events on your tracks.  Once you route to many of the resources in your area, the game can play on auto-pilot, somewhat.Is it worth $10 which Steam has it listed for??  If you like trains, like to play new Sim/Stradegy games, then probably.  However, it is an older game and a simple game, which can grow old fast.

												The game is a definitve setback from the older Railroad Tycoons.* The routing of trains is awful. One basically has to build an own track per train or they will lock up (or one has to play with easy routing)* The 3D interface makes it very difficult to lay track as one likes it. Especially the way height is overscaled looks ludicrious (the Western US seemingly mainly consists of peaks and valeys). Also one can only zoom out very slightly, giving no good overview of the landscape.* The economy model is quite simpel. Lots of X delivered somewhere => Price of X decrease slightly everywhere (if the fluctuations were even caused by delivery action). You can overdeliver a good to an industry (exhausting its storage capacity so it is thrown away) and still get full pay.* The differences between the engines are quite simple. One isn't even told their climbing abilities.* And finally if one wins a scenario (at least if one does it an age earlier than expected) the game crashes to desktop.The older Tycoons were better. A more realistic, albeit more abstract model of railway management is e.g. "Rails across America".

												Just a heads up, you will have to fix the crashing issue by adjusting the size of the .exe header. If you are not comfortable with troubleshooting crash problems, I actually wouldn't recommend this game. If I find the file to adjust the size and the instructions again, I will post it. Now for the second problem to get out of the way: the game automatically places trains on your tracks. Very often you will have open track for a train to use, and the game will unfortunately use track that already has a train on it, causing both trains to be stuck if set on the highest routing difficulty. There are also a number of smaller things to keep an eye on where a small slip might be confusing for a while at first. Sometimes you forget to put a depot somewhere at all, sometimes your track doesn't reach the depot, things like that. It will generally be frustrating at first. Finally, multiplayer is based on Gamespy, and thus doesn't work. However, once the crashing is fixed, and once you learn how to make up for the routing problems (which you shouldn't have to), it really is a fun game. At first I thought it was going to be too easy, as I quickly moved up the difficulty ranks until I was at all but the highest difficulty level. Then for whatever reason I started doing worse, so now I play on medium difficult (mogul). There is a fast forward option for the late game phase when you are often just saving up enough money to buy out another rr. You can also pause it, and do stuff while it is paused. It is generally very laid back, but not too easy. Somehow I want to compare it to a more skill-based version of monopoly, I suppose because you are trying to buy out your opposition. Unlike Monopoly, it is nice to have a certain amount of cash available instead of buying up everything right away, since other characters can start auctions at any time. The fact that you can keep an eye on your opponent's current cash can give you very helpful insight into their intentions, though. In short, this game is not recommended for those who are easily frustrated. With a little work, both in getting it to work at all and learning the unfairly bad train placement, this game works fine and is pretty laid back without being too easy.

												I enjoy playing this game online with my friends (using a CD install, the 1.1 patch, the RailRoads.exe fix & GameRanger)  but its not my favourite game for making railway networks: Open TTD is (with its 32 bit graphics texture pack & the "Pineapple" trains texture pack enabled) because like in TTD, players can place signals for their trains to follow.Things I like about SMR:* Its 3D graphics and presentation.* Its train engine selection screen.* Its selection of trains engines with a different set of engines for different countries.* Its sound effects & music.* Its intuitive interface.* Its economy and share trading gameplay mechanics.* Its patent and town industry auction auctions.* Multiplayer games can be saved (like in Open TTD)Things I don't like:* The Steam and disk releases aren't patched to allow it to use more than 2GB of RAM: so players who have a computer with more than 2GB of RAM must download a fan provided .exe patch to prevent their game from frequently crashing.* A problem all the Railroad Tycoon series games have (except maybe RRT 1): Players can't make proper railway networks because they can't manually place signals for their trains to follow preventing them from making single direction railway lines and double line loops. Instead a train will always take the shortest route to its next station. So players must either make trains share bidirectional rail lines, stopping in passing places to pass each other (or driving through each other if easy/medium difficulty routing is enabled) or they can opt for the efficient, cost effective, unrealistic option of having one train per bidirectional rail line.Internet gaming requires the use of free third party software like GameRanger or VPN software like Tunngle: this game's developers could have given its players a "direct IP connection" option. I've not been able to make my Steam copy work with GameRanger but my CD copy does.The RAM fix:http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=1090651
